text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm with crispy farro cakes that's
right like most 50 year olds these days
i've been trying to cut back on the bad
carbs and eat more of these what they
call ancient grains which is not that
easy since they're almost nothing like
french fries but with these crispy farro
cakes i think we have something that's
both very nutritious and thanks to the
texture this technique provides very fun
to eat so let's go ahead and get started
with a star of the show farro and you
have to admit it really does look like
an ancient grain in fact you know how
when you're watching one of those
history shows they always have someone
pouring grain out of a bag for some
reason this is the grain they always use
for that shot but anyway just a little
behind-the-scenes minutia from a
Hollywood insider and what we'll need to
do before we can make crispy cakes is
cook this grain very very tender so I'm
gonna go ahead and add a cup of farro to
some nice cold fresh water to which we
will add some salt as well as a couple
sprigs of thyme I'm also going to toss
in a couple cloves of crushed garlic as
well as some finely diced onions and as
you can see I'm using a red onion but
any onions are going to work here and
what we'll do is we'll give that a stir
and bring that up to a boil on high heat
and no you don't have to skim that foam
it's harmless and then all we want to do
is reduce our heat to low cover this and
cook it for about 40 to 45 minutes or
until that grain is very tender it sure
if you want to give it a stir during the
cooking process go ahead but like I said
we're going to cook that cover it on low
for about 45 minutes at which point it
should look something like this
and I could tell just by stir in mind it
was ready but if you're not sure give it
a taste and like I said those grains
should be perfectly tender if they're
too firm this stuff's not going to be
starchy enough to stay together as cakes
but assuming you've cooked yours long
enough what we're going to do next is
drain this very well so we'll dump that
into a strainer and let it sit there for
at least 5 to 10 minutes and while
straining if you do happen to notice the
thyme sprigs you can go ahead and pull
those out they have served their purpose
and please do not under any
circumstances rinse this off alright
this should go nowhere near your sink
and by the way I really wanted to make a
farro faucet joke here but unfortunately
I couldn't
are out how to work it in and then once
our Faro has drained for about ten
minutes we will transfer it into a
mixing bowl and while still hot add the
rest of the ingredients so at this point
we'll go ahead and toss in some finely
diced red pepper which is going to
provide a little bit of sweetness but
more importantly a little bit of
bitterness we also want a nice big pinch
of freshly ground black pepper as well
as some freshly and finely grated
Reggiano parmesan we also want to toss
in one large egg and then last but not
least a little touch of cayenne and then
we'll take a spatula and mix this
thoroughly so we will give that a
thorough mixing and I'm gonna go ahead
and smooth out the top for really no
apparent reason and then what we want to
do is let this cool to room temp before
we put it in the fridge not that it
would affect this well you just want to
put hot stuff in your fridge not a good
idea so let it cool down to about room
temp at which point we can cover that in
plastic and pop it in the fridge until
thoroughly chilled which is probably
going to take about an hour and once our
mixture is thoroughly chilled we can
unwrap it and start making crispy cakes
and fair warning even though this is
chilled because we didn't use any
fillers to bind this like flour or bread
crumb it's going to be impossible to
form cakes with your hands so what I'm
going to do is pack this ice cream scoop
with the mixture and use that to
transfer it into my saute pan and by the
way in case you're wondering we are
frying these in a generous amount of
olive oil set over medium-high heat and
if you don't have a scoop no problem
just use your spoon to make a similar
sized pile so I'm gonna go ahead and
make three because that's what fits in
this pan and once the mixture is
transferred in we will carefully flatten
that out with our spatula but don't
press it too thin otherwise these are
going to fall apart when we flip them so
as I just mentioned we're not using any
filler in this there's no bread crumb
there's no flour there's no oatmeal yes
the egg is going to help a little bit
but really not enough to hold these
together unless we have a very very
well-formed crust and generally what
I'll do is I'll start this on medium
high and then once it looks like they're
frying nicely I'll back it down to
medium and just leave it on medium the
rest of the way but anyway as I mention
we're going to let that first side crust
up very nicely before we try to flip it
which is going to take I'm going to
guess about four or five minutes which
is about how long my need to cook at
this point and I can kind of see the
edges we're getting quite brown
as well as you can kind of feel with
your spatula so at this point I decided
they were ready to flip which by the way
you're going to need to do with
confidence so don't hesitate when the
time is where I give a flip and
visualize them not falling apart which
happily mine did not all right so we
really have to trust our crust here and
yes this would be easier if we did use
some filler to hold these together but
then we're not talking about pure
Farrell cakes so while this technique is
fraught with danger the final product is
going to be totally worth it
because you're going to be enjoying pure
crispy farro goodness and then to finish
these we're simply going to do the same
thing to the other side let it cook for
about four or five minutes until we have
a very beautiful crispy crust so I went
ahead and I let that second side crisp
up nicely
at which point it was time to serve
these up and since I'm just doing a
little appetizer here I'm going to serve
one cake per person which I decide to
top with some creme fraiche as well as a
nice spoon of beautiful golden trout roe
which I'll go ahead and call caviar
because it sounds fancier and we'll
finish up with the obligatory sprinkling
of chives and our crispy farro cake is
done and I could talk about how good
this looks but I much rather grab a fork
and dig right in and this really was
fantastic that cake was crispy and
comforting and that tangy cream and
briny Nero were just perfect with this
although I really did need twice as much
of both but to be honest I didn't want
to ruin the pictures and then just in
case you're wondering sure it looks
crispy but is it really crispy
they don't take my word for it listen
for yourself that is some serious
serious Chris penis and while the creme
fraiche and caviar were very nice on
this your mind should be reeling right
now with possibilities
I mean imagine this as a base for Eggs
Benedict or maybe we'll toss in some
grated cheddar and apple and fry these
up and serve them next to some pork
chops oh man that sounds good if I've
trained you guys properly and I'd like
to think that I have you guys should be
able to come up with all kinds of
different ways to use this for fun and
profit I mean you are after all the
Charro of your faro hashtag
coochie-coochie ironically most of the
people that would understand that
reference have no idea what a hashtag is
but anyway I really do hope you give
these a try soon head over to food
wishes
for all the ingredient amounts and
Morpho as usual and as always enjoy
